title: Disciplinary cases tripled at Harvard due to pro-Palestine protests, student newspaper reports
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Disciplinary cases at Harvard University tripled in the 2023-2024 academic year due to pro-Palestine protests.
Over half of the 90 disciplined students were involved in a November 2023 occupation and an April 2024 encampment.
Protests led to tightened rules, with 58 students on probation and tensions over actions against campus protestors.

title: Photos: Music, Guinness, and lots of rain at Day 1 of Seisiún Irish music festival in Boston
author: Boston.com
bullets: Day 1 of the Seisiún Irish music festival featured performances at Suffolk Downs despite severe weather.
Notable acts included the Dropkick Murphys, The Hold Steady, The Scratch, and The Rumjacks.
Heavy rain led to temporary evacuations, but attendees returned to enjoy more music and Guinness.

title: Fear and Loathing in New England
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Ralph Steadman is featured in a free retrospective in Maine, showcasing his 60-year art career at Bates College Museum.
Steadman recounts a Newport incident in 1970 with Hunter S. Thompson involving psilocybin and a yacht painting attempt.
The exhibit highlights Steadman's collaborations with Thompson and includes screenings and a closing discussion through October 11.

title: New report outlines how many people might lose SNAP in Greater Boston under Trump bill
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: 7% of Boston-area SNAP recipients may lose benefits under Trump's bill, affecting around 40,000 adults.
9,600 legally present immigrants in Massachusetts could lose SNAP eligibility with the new rules.
Massachusetts to cover 75% of SNAP administrative costs, up from 50%, adding $58 million to the state's budget.

title: 3 takeaways from the Revolution’s 3-2 loss vs. the Chicago Fire
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Revolution fall 3-2 to Chicago Fire, severely damaging playoff hopes; New England's record now 8-14-7.
Early goals from Jonathan Bamba and Philip Zinckernagel put Chicago ahead before Revolution's late comeback attempt.
Coach Caleb Porter accepts blame, stating poor defensive setup allowed Chicago to exploit midfield space.

title: Boston’s preliminary election is almost here. Here’s who will be on the ballot
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston's preliminary election on Sept. 9 will narrow candidates for mayor and City Council for the Nov. 4 general election.
Mayor Michelle Wu faces challengers including Josh Kraft and Robert Cappucci, with the top two advancing to the general election.
Ten candidates vie for four at-large City Council positions, while certain district councilors run unopposed or in limited races.

title: Maren Morris brings her divorce album to Leader Bank Pavilion
author: Marc Hirsh
bullets: Maren Morris performed her entire divorce-themed album 'Dreamsicle' at Leader Bank Pavilion in Boston.
Audience engaged actively with Morris's performance, particularly during songs like 'Lemonade' and 'Too Good'.
Sound issues affected clarity, but Morris's powerful vocals and stage presence carried the show.

title: Alex Cora provides injury update for Wilyer Abreu, doesn’t give timetable for return
author: Colin McCarthy
bullets: Wilyer Abreu is progressing from a calf strain but remains far from returning to the Red Sox lineup.
Manager Alex Cora noted Abreu ran but not at full speed, indicating a positive step forward but no return timeline.
With 19 regular season games left, Abreu's prolonged absence thins Boston's outfield options ahead of a potential postseason.

title: What oddsmakers are projecting for Patriots, Drake Maye on eve of 2025 season
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Oddsmakers set the Patriots' 2025 win total at 8.5, reflecting higher expectations than previous years.
Drake Maye's odds for winning MVP are +5000; he is projected to throw for 3,330.5 yards and 20.5 touchdowns.
Mike Vrabel is the favorite for Coach of the Year, with odds of +600, leading the Patriots into the new season.

title: Patriots were reportedly among teams who checked in on Micah Parsons before trade
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Patriots considered acquiring Micah Parsons before the Cowboys traded him to the Packers in August.
Dallas sought two first-round picks and a 'significant player' in exchange for Parsons, per The Athletic.
Parsons signed a four-year, $188 million extension with the Packers, becoming the highest-paid non-quarterback in NFL history.
